skill.name: rn-navigation
skill.description: Expo Router navigation patterns for React Native. Use when implementing navigation, routing, deep links, tab bars, modals, or handling navigation state in Expo apps.
skill.summary: Expo Router navigation patterns for React Native apps with tab bars, modals, and deep links.
skill.author: CJHarmath

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill for React Native navigation patterns. Static findings are false positives: backtick patterns are markdown code formatting, cryptographic alerts are scanner noise on text patterns, and URLs are legitimate metadata. No executable code or security concerns detected.

content.value_statement: React Native apps require proper navigation architecture for tab bars, modals, and deep linking. This skill provides proven Expo Router patterns for production apps.
actual_capabilities: Create nested navigation stacks with Expo Router
Configure tab bars with proper state management
Implement deep linking for push notifications
Build modal presentations with shared element transitions
Structure navigation directories for scalable apps
limitations: Does not include native navigation performance optimization
No authentication or protected route patterns
Third-party navigation library integration not included

use_cases.title: Mobile Developer Building New App
use_cases.description: Set up navigation structure for a new Expo app with tabs, stacks, and deep links following production patterns.
use_cases.target_user: Mobile developers starting new React Native projects

use_cases.title: Team Adding Complex Navigation
use_cases.description: Refactor existing navigation to support modals, nested routes, and proper deep linking configuration.
use_cases.target_user: Teams maintaining Expo apps with growing complexity

use_cases.title: Developer Debugging Navigation Issues
use_cases.description: Diagnose navigation state problems, deep link handling failures, or tab bar rendering issues.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Navigation Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Expo Router navigation structure for a React Native app with a tab bar containing Home, Profile, and Settings screens. Include a nested stack for Settings with notifications and privacy options.
prompt_templates.scenario: Setting up basic tab and stack navigation

prompt_templates.title: Deep Link Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure deep linking for an Expo app so that custom URL scheme://profile/settings opens the Settings stack to the Privacy screen. Show the necessary configuration in app.json and the linking hook implementation.
prompt_templates.scenario: Implementing deep linking for push notifications

prompt_templates.title: Modal Navigation Pattern
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement a modal presentation pattern using Expo Router where the modal slides up from the bottom with a backdrop blur. Include proper dismissal with gesture support.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating modal presentations with shared transitions

prompt_templates.title: Navigation State Persistence
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement navigation state persistence using AsyncStorage so users return to their exact screen position after app restart. Handle the restoration logic for nested navigation state.
prompt_templates.scenario: Persisting navigation state across app restarts

output_examples.input: Create an app with bottom tabs for Feed, Search, and Profile. Add a FAB button in the center that opens a Compose modal.
Set up deep links so that myapp://messages/123 opens the chat screen for conversation 123

best_practices: Use the (group) folder convention to organize navigation stacks and manage shared layouts
Configure deep linking prefixes early to avoid path resolution issues in production
Test navigation on both iOS and Android since gesture behaviors differ between platforms
anti_patterns: Avoid mixing React Navigation and Expo Router in the same app
Do not hardcode deep link URLs in components; use dynamic path generation
Avoid deep navigation state mutations without proper error boundaries

faq.question: How do I handle authentication guards with Expo Router?
faq.answer: Use conditional rendering in the root layout based on auth state. Redirect unauthenticated users to a dedicated auth flow using router.replace() when needed.

faq.question: Can I use Expo Router with React Native Fabric components?
faq.answer: Yes, Expo Router 3.0+ supports Fabric. Wrap your app in GestureHandlerRootView for proper gesture handling with both classic and Fabric components.

faq.question: How do I pass parameters between screens in Expo Router?
faq.answer: Use the params object in the href prop: href={{ pathname: '/profile', params: { userId: '123' } }}. Access params via useLocalSearchParams() hook.

faq.question: What is the difference between Stack and Tabs components?
faq.answer: Stack manages hierarchical navigation for drill-down flows. Tabs provides a bottom bar for switching between top-level views. Combine them by nesting Stack inside Tabs or vice versa.

faq.question: How do I handle Android back button in Expo Router?
faq.answer: Expo Router handles Android back button automatically for most cases. Use useBackButtonHook() for custom behavior or router.canGoBack() to check navigation state.

faq.question: Can I animate screen transitions in Expo Router?
faq.answer: Yes, use the animation prop on Stack.Screen. Options include 'default', 'fade', 'slide_from_right', 'slide_from_left', 'fade_from_bottom', and 'none'.
